title: Introduction to rgbio
text: rgbio provides high-performance interface gb-io Rust crate reading writing GenBank files. designed fast memory-efficient providing R-friendly data structures. Important note: package written primarily LLMs (“AI”) direction, uses robust Rust gb-io crate tested ~50 diverse GenBank files many edge cases. project play around agentic coding, provides real value one ways write GenBank files R.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: rgbio package available CRAN (now), depends Rust crate. can install R-universe repository without installed Rust Rust toolchain, binary versions available Windows, macOS, Linux. pre-built binary available system, want latest development version, can install rgbio GitHub, provided Rust toolchain installed. can find information install Rust https://github.com/r-rust/hellorust.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: write GenBank file tidy mode, typically provide: 1. Sequences: named character vector (DNAStringSet). 2. Features: data.frame columns type, start, end, strand, qualifiers. 3. Metadata: list, data.frame, DataFrame record-level attributes. Let’s create minimal example sequence. Now, write temporary file:
code: # 1. The sequence seq_dna <- "ATGCGTACGTTAGC"  # 2. Metadata metadata <- list(   definition = "Synthetic Example Sequence",   accession = "EX0001",   version = "1",   molecule_type = "DNA",   topology = "linear",   division = "SYN",   date = "01-JAN-2023" )  # 3. Features # Note: 'qualifiers' must be a list column where each element is a named character vector. features_df <- data.frame(   type = c("source", "gene", "CDS"),   start = c(1L, 1L, 1L),   end = c(14L, 14L, 14L),   strand = c("+", "+", "+"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  features_df$qualifiers <- list(   c(organism = "Synthetic Organism", mol_type = "genomic DNA"),   c(gene = "exampleGene"),   c(gene = "exampleGene", product = "hypothetical protein", translation = "MRTS") )  # Preview features print(features_df) #>     type start end strand                              qualifiers #> 1 source     1  14      +         Synthetic Organism, genomic DNA #> 2   gene     1  14      +                             exampleGene #> 3    CDS     1  14      + exampleGene, hypothetical protein, MRTS tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".gb") write_gbk(   file = tmp_file,   sequences = c(EX0001 = seq_dna),   features = features_df,   metadata = metadata ) #> [1] TRUE

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: Reading straightforward. read_gbk parses file can return tidy tables.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: returned object three components matching wrote. Metadata: Sequence: Features: features returned tidy data.frame.
code: str(records$metadata) #> tibble [1 × 13] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ record_id    : chr "EX0001" #>  $ name         : chr "EX0001" #>  $ definition   : chr "Synthetic Example Sequence" #>  $ accession    : chr "EX0001" #>  $ version      : chr "1" #>  $ keywords     :List of 1 #>   ..$ : chr(0)  #>  $ source       : chr "" #>  $ organism     : chr NA #>  $ molecule_type: chr "DNA" #>  $ topology     : chr "linear" #>  $ division     : chr "SYN" #>  $ date         : chr "01-JAN-2023" #>  $ references   :List of 1 #>   ..$ : list() records$sequences$sequence[[1]] #> [1] "ATGCGTACGTTAGC" print(records$features) #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>   record_id type   start   end strand qualifiers #>   <chr>     <chr>  <int> <int> <chr>  <I<list>>  #> 1 EX0001    source     1    14 +      <chr [2]>  #> 2 EX0001    gene       1    14 +      <chr [1]>  #> 3 EX0001    CDS        1    14 +      <chr [3]>

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: can also use Bioconductor-native classes input output.
code: seqs_bioc <- Biostrings::DNAStringSet(c(EX0002 = "ATGCGGTTAA"))  gr <- GenomicRanges::GRanges(   seqnames = "EX0002",   ranges = IRanges::IRanges(start = c(1L, 1L), end = c(10L, 10L)),   strand = c("+", "+") ) S4Vectors::mcols(gr)$type <- c("source", "gene") S4Vectors::mcols(gr)$qualifiers <- list(   c(organism = "Synthetic Organism", mol_type = "genomic DNA"),   c(gene = "exampleGene2") )  meta_bioc <- S4Vectors::DataFrame(   definition = "Bioconductor input example",   accession = "EX0002",   molecule_type = "DNA" )  tmp_bioc <- tempfile(fileext = ".gb") write_gbk(   file = tmp_bioc,   sequences = seqs_bioc,   features = gr,   metadata = meta_bioc ) #> [1] TRUE  bioc_out <- read_gbk(tmp_bioc, format = "bioconductor") class(bioc_out$sequences) #> [1] "DNAStringSet" #> attr(,"package") #> [1] "Biostrings" class(bioc_out$features) #> [1] "GRanges" #> attr(,"package") #> [1] "GenomicRanges" class(bioc_out$metadata) #> [1] "DFrame" #> attr(,"package") #> [1] "S4Vectors"

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: Absolute minimum required inputs: file: output file path. sequences: non-empty named character vector DNAStringSet non-empty sequence strings. Everything else optional: features: optional (NULL valid). metadata: optional (NULL valid). omitted, rgbio fills required record-level fields using sequence names: name, definition, accession default record name. molecule_type defaults "DNA". Practical note: append = TRUE requires file already exists valid GenBank file.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: following metadata fields supported write_gbk() returned read_gbk(): name (Locus name) definition accession version keywords (character vector) source organism molecule_type (e.g., “DNA”) division topology (“linear” “circular”) date (format: DD-MON-YYYY) references (list references; reference may include description, authors, consortium, title, journal, pubmed, remark)

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: reading GenBank files, rgbio preserves feature locations GenBank location expressions produced parser, including patterns : join(1..10,20..30) complement(100..200) fuzzy bounds <5..>120 words, rgbio focuses faithful /O location syntax rather fully symbolic location algebra. advanced manipulations (interval arithmetic, set operations, transcript/CDS composition), use Bioconductor range tooling GRanges output parse location strings specialized utilities.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: rgbio leverages Rust’s zero-copy parsing possible efficient string handling outperform pure R implementations, especially large multi-record GenBank files.

title: rgbio
text: rgbio package available CRAN (now), depends Rust crate. can install R-universe repository without installed Rust Rust toolchain, binary versions available Windows, macOS, Linux. pre-built binary available system, want current development snapshot, can install rgbio GitHub, provided Rust toolchain installed. can find information install Rust https://github.com/r-rust/hellorust.

title: rgbio
code: library(rgbio)  # Minimal example seq_dna <- "ATGCGTACGTTAGC" metadata <- list(   definition = "Synthetic Example Sequence",   accession = "EX0001",   version = "1",   molecule_type = "DNA",   topology = "linear",   division = "SYN",   date = "01-JAN-2023" )  features_df <- data.frame(   type = c("source", "gene", "CDS"),   start = c(1L, 1L, 1L),   end = c(14L, 14L, 14L),   strand = c("+", "+", "+"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  features_df$qualifiers <- list(   c(organism = "Synthetic Organism", mol_type = "genomic DNA"),   c(gene = "exampleGene"),   c(gene = "exampleGene", product = "hypothetical protein", translation = "MRTS") )  tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".gb") write_gbk(   file = tmp_file,   sequences = c(EX0001 = seq_dna),   features = features_df,   metadata = metadata )  records <- read_gbk(tmp_file, format = "tidy") str(records)

what: What Is Required vs Optional for write_gbk()
title: rgbio
text: Minimum required inputs: file: output file path sequences: non-empty named character vector DNAStringSet Optional inputs: features = NULL metadata = NULL append = FALSE validate = TRUE line_width = 80 metadata omitted, rgbio fills defaults per record: name, definition, accession sequence name molecule_type = "DNA" append = TRUE requires target file already exists valid GenBank file.

title: rgbio
code: library(rgbio)  out <- tempfile(fileext = ".gb")  write_gbk(   file = out,   sequences = c(min1 = "ATGC") )  read_gbk(out, format = "tidy")

title: rgbio
code: library(rgbio)  out <- tempfile(fileext = ".gb")  seqs <- Biostrings::DNAStringSet(c(min2 = "ATGCGG")) write_gbk(   file = out,   sequences = seqs )  read_gbk(out, format = "bioconductor")

title: rgbio
text: main vignette available via:

title: Read a GenBank file — read_gbk
text: Reads one GenBank records returns selected components either Bioconductor tidy format.

title: Read a GenBank file — read_gbk
code: read_gbk(   file,   format = "bioconductor",   sequences = TRUE,   features = TRUE,   metadata = TRUE,   records = NULL,   validate = TRUE )

title: Read a GenBank file — read_gbk
text: file Character path GenBank file. format Output format. One "bioconductor" "tidy". sequences Logical; include sequence data. features Logical; include feature annotations. metadata Logical; include record metadata. records Integer indices character accession/name selectors. validate Logical; validate parsed records.

title: Read a GenBank file — read_gbk
text: variable object based selected components. Returns either single object named list sequences, features, /metadata.

title: Read a GenBank file — read_genbank
text: Deprecated compatibility wrapper read_gbk().

title: Read a GenBank file — read_genbank
text: file Path GenBank file.

title: Read a GenBank file — read_genbank
text: Parsed records legacy list format.

title: Write GenBank records — write_gbk
text: Writes GenBank records sequence, feature, metadata components.

title: Write GenBank records — write_gbk
code: write_gbk(   file,   sequences,   features = NULL,   metadata = NULL,   append = FALSE,   validate = TRUE,   line_width = 80 )

title: Write GenBank records — write_gbk
text: file Character path output file. sequences DNAStringSet named character vector. features GRanges type qualifiers mcols(), tidy feature table columns type, start, end, strand, qualifiers. metadata DataFrame, data.frame, list record metadata. append Logical; append file. validate Logical; validate inputs. line_width Integer sequence line width.

title: Write GenBank records — write_gbk
text: Logical TRUE success.

title: Write a GenBank file — write_genbank
text: Deprecated compatibility wrapper write_gbk().

title: Write a GenBank file — write_genbank
text: file Path output file. sequence Sequence string. features Feature table columns key, location, qualifiers. metadata Metadata list.

title: Write a GenBank file — write_genbank
text: Logical TRUE success.

title: rgbio 0.2.0
text: Initial full release Added new primary GenBank /O API: read_gbk() write_gbk(). Added format = "tidy" format = "bioconductor" output modes reading. Added selective read controls (sequences, features, metadata) record selectors (records). Added write support named character vectors DNAStringSet sequence inputs. Added multi-record write orchestration append-mode writing. Kept read_genbank() write_genbank() deprecated compatibility wrappers. Added extensive testing test files gb-io.py, gb-io, biopython

title: rgbio 0.1.0
text: intermediate release r-universe

title: rgbio 0.0.0.9000
text: Initial development version read/write support GenBank files. R bindings Rust gb-io crate via extendr. Test coverage includes NCBI example GenBank files.
